comments.commentBody: ReaganAnd30:  There is no left because it was destroyed after the 1930's by the anti-Communist crusade of the Establishment.  I wonder if we are now seeing the blowback: the grasp of the greedy rich has taken so much from the people that it is disenchanting them, but with no left, the only place they can go is the crazy right.  Which is well funded and entrenched as a result of the destruction of its only real opposition (the left) and its assistance in the hysterical anti-Communism of the 40's, 50's, etc.
The less clearly they are thinking and the more predictable their behavior -- guided by the manipulators supreme (the best in history, alas for us).

@Thomas: Read this board and note the way people describe the Republican faithful and you might notice something, i.e., the descriptions are typically highly insulting.
Imagine you are, say, white, southern, Christian, educated, a successful businessman, devoted to family, clean, no dope, no legal issues, worked your way up from nothing, et cetera.
You see liberals calling you an idiot, a buffoon, a racist, greedy, insane, evil, and so on?
Your crime?
Success?
Creating jobs and hiring people to work for your company?
Help me out here...why would these people trust or embrace or even listen to Democrats, ever?
You know I am not religious and I am not especially political...I do not even know what most of the candidates look like. But I do know that calling people ugly, childish names will get you nowhere.
It's group think at its worst, demonizing and deriding the opposition without the slightest inkling of how utterly fatal that is to the goal of creating an enlightened society.

@Alex S:  You are asking the right question.  The collapse of the GOP has been expected (by certain people) for several years now.  Instead, they control more states than ever and are unrestrained in enforcing their agendas upon the people of those states, who are often largely opposed to those agendas.

@buffcrone. Well despite my interference with her math education  by helping her color my daughter somehow made it through her college multivariable calculus and differential equations classes while pursuing  a double engineering degree at an elite university. It's truly a wonder.

@tao:  Much science fiction is philosophical in the same sense as Ayn Rand.  I read one page of "Atlas Shrugged" over someone's shoulder in an airplane and realized I would throw up if I had to plow through her incompetent prose.  As for Asimov, the "Foundation Trilogy" still is readable -- the prose is pedestrian (which is better than Rand's) but the ideas and their realization by action are captivating.  Alternative analysis:  I loved it so much when young that I can still enjoy it no matter what.

As far as I know France had no stake in Iraq2, just to the contrary, they strongly discouraged (recall the freedom fries?). Yes, many of us considered and still do consider that a wrong war.

No reason to brutally murder 150+ people and as such your reasoning is a complete false equivalency. These people are disgusting and the god they pray so enthusiastically to is more like the devil.

Have any of the attacks occurred on American soil? When those foreign countries pay taxes here - then the President is responsible for their protection. Therefore your rambling makes no sense. It is the bush administration that is responsible for terrorist attacks on American soil 9/11 and creating the debacle that continues in middle east.

How wrong the jihadists and their backers are to think we Westerners are docile and submissive. They will soon enough see how fierce and formidable an enemy we can be.
The victims of these cowardly attacks today will not have died in vain: our way of life isn't going anywhere.
You're dreaming if you think this Sunni-Shiite armageddon, with spillover into Europe, wouldn't have happened without George Bush. And besides, what's you're solution now?

I'm all for bringing Bush & Cheney to court. What they did was a disaster.
But this did not start with 9/11 and the invasion of Iraq. Islamic-fundamentalist terrorism goes back decades (if not centuries). Throughout the 70s to 90s there were many incidents.

Here's a list for any who need their memories refreshed.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Islamist_terrorist_attacks

Dick Cheney and George W. Bush, the gifts that keep on giving.  This is what happens when you falsify information to push (I wouldn't say lead) a nation to war against the wrong opponent.  Actions have consequences, but not apparently for the war criminals who start them.

Wrong... it was Obama and his allies who destabilized Libya and Syria which has led to ISIS  and the Muslim migrant infestation. It was Obama who armed Syrian "moderates" and those arms ended up with ISIS.

Paris je t aime! This is the second time in two years that my city has been bloodied by cowards. I do not wish for revenge, as only more innocents will suffer. What I do ask for is accountability! And this accountability must start in my second home the United States. Our prior administration launched a criminal war in Iraq, failed miserably in their attempt at nation building, and in turn caused ISIS. If we do not hold our own leaders accountable when they have lied and caused over half million civilian deaths, who are we to demand justice on a bunch of brainwashed idiots who are legitimized by our inability, lack of desire to prosecute our own. Furthermore we support states like Saudi Arabia (who was clearly more involved in the 9-11 attacks than Iraq) or Qatar, that are known for supporting these extremist. We have created and enabled others to create these monsters and the creators need to be held accountable. Otherwise all these persons will have been lost for nothing .
Encore une fois Paris je t aime!

Does anyone seriously believe that this conflict within the EU will get better? The east and the west have been at each others' throats for 1500 years. This is just the latest incarnation of that cultural struggle and I see no reason why it will end any time soon. The irony is that the battle will ultimately be won not in the streets or on the battlefields, but in the wombs of women - which demographic will ultimately become the majority population in democratic Europe through the simple expedient of producing more babies? There is nothing wrong with that outcome, but it is unfortunate that so much blood has to be shed by those unwilling to wait a few generations for the inevitable passive shift in power.
Really, not realistic. When in history has evll ever been dealt with by reason? I'm pretty sure that people who wantonly behead innocents are pleased to read comments from appeasers
Then they can have around 35,000 additional gun deaths a year like the US - good idea.

The thought that a couple of concert goers with carry-permits would have stopped trained assassins with automatic weapons is a fantasy fueled by western TV and movies. And if you had enough weapons in concert goers' hands to have overcome the assault, you would see a lot more gun deaths in Paris from all those "legal" guns than you currently see from terrorism. Police presence might be a different story, but arming ordinary citizens is a recipe for disaster - more than 10,000 Americans are killed in gun homicides each year.
http://www.vox.com/2015/10/1/9437187/obama-guns-terrorism-deaths

Clearly, when a government can no longer protect its citizens, it has no more legitimacy, which is the point of the attacks.

However, despite the absolute laws of no guns for French citizens, a Bill of Rights with a Second Amendment might have helped, especially a couple of concert goers with carry-permits--not so much time to casually execute the innocent.

Hollande's closing of the borders is a bit late, like a decade.

Frequency is probably one factor - rightly or not, the general American/Western default view is one in which explosions and attacks originating anywhere in the Middle East/North Africa are as commonplace as a traffic accident.
A mild Friday evening in such an iconic city as Paris, however - it strikes at something about which Americans are far more concerned: that such an attack could possibly happen in our own iconic cities, or elsewhere in our country. It feels far more like a direct attack on our "way of life," so to speak, whereas our collective mindset tends to be a sense that all of "those areas" are a never-ending, non-stop stream of suicide bombers, shooting attacks, and explosions.
It isn't right - the life of an innocent Parisian man, woman, or child is equal in value to that of an innocent Lebanese man, woman, or child. But it has become a seemingly collective mindset: "those things" happen in "those places," far away from us. Thus, when they happen in Paris or London or Madrid or NYC, our vulnerability feels raw and exposed.

We visited Uzbekistan several years ago and were surprised to learn that citizens who left the country were not allowed to return -- ever -- for fear that they may have become radicalized and may have become terrorists.  Perhaps the European nations who are now accepting Middle Eastern refuges should declare that those who have immigrated from Middle Eastern countries in the past 15 years should not be allowed to return to any country in Europe if they have left Europe.

I doubt it's a coincidence that the killers chose the performance by a group named  Eagles of Death Metal. Sorry, but the very title of the band seems to glorify death. I don't know why they do and I don't know why they are so popular - but it's not chance.

Something is terribly wrong-headed when people who gather to celebrate singing, partake in a friendly play, or sit together to share bread, butter and wine are attacked and obliterated. Where does this enmity come from for what engenders life and levity in our hearts and imagination, I would never understand. But I do know those who know how to pay homage to life will not be deterred; they will come out in throngs to sing and laugh and share food.

I like the dashing way you suggest "lighting them up like Dresden"--it reminds me of one of our greatest films, "Slaughterhouse 5'" which depicts the astounding consequences of doing just that, to a target of mostly civilians, in a war that made it permissible to do so.

My tolerance for the chaos in the middle east and radical Muslims has reached zero. It's time right wing Republicans and progressives join in common cause to exterminate - that's right - using the style so often mentioned in discussions about WWII. Light them up like Dresden.

If I have to choose between my life and theirs, they need to die.

Muslin terrorism needs to be blown to death. War is ugly. Terrorism is war against us.

It is time to fight fire with fire. As we did with the Nazis during World War II, our military did what was necessary to defeat that scourge. I dare say that radical Islam is just as bad; they want to impose their way of thinking on all of all and to dominate the world.
Now, the civilized world--the Americans, Europeans, Russians, Chinese--must unite against this threat. It is time we take all the steps necessary to eradicate it from the face of the earth now. Yes, it is World War III
I hope that the French President is true to his word when he says that France will wage a merciless war on the surviving conspirators.  However, I really doubt that will happen.

This violence makes victims of us all.
Those who lost their lives. Those who lost loved ones. Those who fear they may be next. Those whose Middle Eastern heritage marks them as suspects.
I have dear friends who, as Muslims, only wish to live in peace, along with all of us who abhor this violence. We all grieve for France. And Freedom, which provides, unfortunately, an opportunity for violence and hatred to touch us all.
could not agree more. American social media companies are pouring unprecedented fuel on this fire.  Why is this not being stopped? There are limits to free speech.
They had suicide vests on and blew themselves up. I don't think armed citizens would have deterred them.

Uh? The killed themselves with suicide vests. I doubt the fear of getting shot was an issue.
What we need is a unified world response to these monsters. Not more civilians with guns up against guys with suicide vests.
I do love the prospect of attending a rock concert or being among overflow fans at a huge soccer venue, knowing that everyone is packing major heat, and is eager to use it...

I am much surprised by what I am going to say, but I can't help it. Perhaps if people are allowed carrying weapons with them any time, these cowards wouldn't have thought of shooting unarmed people the way they did.
I agree, but there's also been the Saudis for the past 40  years spreading this extremist Islam around the world, backed by massive wealth. I think that is where it starts.
@md:  You think too small.  Retirement funds?  Pharmaceutical industry?  Just players in the Big Game.
